title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO — On a night that belonged to one man, the Atlanta Hawks were merely passengers on a historic ride. Steve Smith didn't just score; he authored a masterpiece, torching the San Antonio Spurs for a career-high 43 points to power the Hawks to a decisive 109-89 road victory in 1997.

From the opening tip, Smith was uncontainable, a symphony of motion and marksmanship. He poured in points from every conceivable angle, slicing through the Spurs' defense and raining down jumpers with cold-blooded precision. The Spurs, helpless to find an answer, could only watch as Smith systematically dismantled them, possession by possession. His 43-point eruption wasn't just a personal best; it was a statement performance that echoed throughout the Alamodome, silencing the home crowd and seizing the spotlight entirely.

While Smith’s brilliance dominated the narrative, he received crucial support. Christian Laettner provided a steadying presence with 12 points and a game-high 12 rebounds, while Dikembe Mutombo anchored the defense with 10 rebounds and 3 blocked shots. The Spurs, overwhelmed by the singular force of Smith, were led by Vinny Del Negro's 20 points and 14 points from Dominique Wilkins, but it was nowhere near enough to counter the avalanche.

Ultimately, the final score was a mere footnote. The real story was the man who wore number 3 for the Hawks. Steve Smith didn't just win a game; he created a lasting memory, a career-defining night where one player's extraordinary talent was so immense it rendered everything else secondary.
